dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLYING OVER England, the green rolling Chiltern hills, ov woodland and villages and country houses. The CAMERA FINDS a handsome manor house. In the field by house, a cricket match is in full swing. EXT. CRICKET FIELD -— DAY 2 MOVING POV - A blur of tree trunks. Railings round a pavilion terrace. Glimpses of women drinking tea on a sun English afternoon. Sounds of a cricket match in progress. The UNKNOWN WATCHER is on the move, trying for a better vantage point. Now at last he catches a clear sighting of DIANA, a beautiful young woman, 22 years old, dark hair, calm manner. She’s seated on the pavilion terrace, surrounded by others but looking as if she’s alone. A you man, TOMMY, is clearly trying to talk to her, one hand nervously fiddling with his straw hat as he does so. Dian seems unaware of his existence. Some other figure crosses the line of vision, obscuring her. The MOVING POV shifts again. This time the watcher gets an even better view of her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dear God. What - is - that? ON ROBIN CAVENDISH, staring. A good-looking 25-year-old, dressed in cricketing whites, wearing pads. With him, als in whites, his friend COLIN CAMPBELL.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Not a chance.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: (gazing at Diana) How so?

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: She’s a famous heart-breaker.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 2.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Do you know her?

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: I know her brothers. A glance towards two young men watching the cricket, identical twins BLOGGS and DAVID BLACKER. They too are watching Diana, amused by Tommy’s utter failure to attrac Diana’s attention. They’re mimicking the way his hand fid with his hat. Robin’s gaze turns from the twins back to Diana. The soun of a wicket being taken, and the clapping of the spectators.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: She’s gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: No one’s ever got near. Martin proposed twice.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Would you marry Martin? I wouldn't. But I would marry me.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: And I’m sure you'd be very happy together, Robin.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: The thing is, I’m running out of time. I leave for Nairobi on July 15th. I need a wife. It’s now his turn to bat. Smiling, confident, he strides to the crease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin prepares to face the bowler. He glances back at Dia on the pavilion terrace: he’s going to make her notice hi But Diana’s only half-watching. She’s bored. Tommy has given up. The ball hurtles towards Robin. He steps forward, smashes the ball with a sweeping off-drive. It sails over the pavilion for a glorious six. A cheer goes up. Diana is chatting to a girlfriend. She didn’t even notice Robin’s triumph.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin with a cup of tea in his hand moving past team mate and supporters, accepting congratulations as he goes. He’ heading for Diana. She sits staring far away at nothing. Still bored. He comes to a stop beside her. She doesn’t register his presence. He drinks his tea, watches her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I know you can see me. Diana turns her lazy gaze to take him in.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you're half as bored as you look.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Do I look bored? I don’t mean to.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Cricket’s a lot more fun to play than to watch.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yes. I suppose it is.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Like life, you might say.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Might you? An older friend, HARRY TENNYSON, comes up to Diana. Harry very overweight, and just walking gets him out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY TENNYSON
dialogues.text: We're off. If you want a lift it’s now or never. Diana gets up.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’m ready.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Will you be at the Barings’ bash on Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I might be.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 4.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Maybe see you there.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Maybe. She goes off with Harry. Robin watches her go, but she doesn’t give a backward glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING POV - Through the throng of guests at the ball: glimpses of Diana, stunning in a formal gown. On her love face the same air of not seeing the bustle round her; of living in some other private world. Robin, smart in his formal evening clothes, tracks her wi his eyes. He moves steadily towards her. She turns, catch his gaze. Holds the look for a moment, then turns away. He reaches her. She shows no sign of noticing him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I could ask you to dance. You could say you don’t feel like dancing right now. I could say, Next time, maybe. And I could saunter away.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You could saunter away.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Or I could just not ask. That’s unexpected. She looks at him, unsure what he means He takes her hand and pulls her onto the dance floor. She’s too taken by surprise to resist. Before she knows what’s happening they’re dancing. He dances very well. She lets him lead her, looking at hi with an amused quizzical look. She likes dancing with him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin’s battered old sports car bowls along an empty country road. Diana sits beside Robin. IN CAR -—  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 5.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: So where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I thought Maidenhead. I know a rather jolly pub by the river. The car turns off into a lane that winds up a hill betwee trees, to come to a stop facing a giant vista of rolling countryside. Robin's favourite view.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: This doesn’t look like a jolly pub by the river.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: No. We seem to have missed our way.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: What a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Lucky I packed a bottle of wine and a pork pie.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Good Lord, is that the time? She reaches for the car door handle. There is no car door handle.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: How do you open the door?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You don’t.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: But I want to get out.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: No you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Don’t I?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You want to kiss me.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: What makes you think I want to - He pulls her towards him and kisses her. No aggression, b nor does he give her any choice in the matter.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 6. For a moment she accepts the kiss passively. Then she starts to kiss him back. Then she starts to kiss him with real passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grounds of Diana’s family home. Diana sits on a swing attached to a branch of a tree. She’s slowly twisting her round and round, winding the two ropes above her. At her on the grass lie her brothers, Bloggs and David.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: (to Diana) You hardly know the little man.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Bloggs) Would you say he’s littler than us? The two brothers eye each other, as if making the mental comparison.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Not much in it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Diana) Has he got any money at all?

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: It’s not like you don’t have other options.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What happened to Hugh? Doesn’t he have a castle in Scotland?

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Mind you, who'd want to live in Scotland?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: She's talking about going to live in Kenya, for God’s sake!

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Diana, please stop going round and round and concentrate. This is your future life we’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Your future happiness. Diana stops twirling. Her feet on the ground hold the swi steady.

dialogues.speaker: 9B
dialogues.text: 9c 10 11 Breathe - Tan Revision - 2 August 2016 7.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: The thing is, I just know this is it. She lifts her feet and the swing spins her round and roun skirts flying, as the ropes unwind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find ourselves flying through a magnificent gorge ravi The searing heat of the bright African light upon us. We over trees and waterfalls, ahead of us a towering mountai Into frame drops a Tiger Moth biplane, flying away from u Its pilot unknown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The biplane, now a tiny speck, flies along a massive clif wall and circles over the planes below. EXT. KENYA 9c The biplane comes in to land. As it taxis and stops, the engines cut. The pilot climbs out of the cockpit, raising goggles, revealing that it is in fact ROBIN. He helps DIA down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING PAST red earth, fields of sugar cane, banana groves. A Landrover jolts down the dusty road. In the Landrover Robin and Diana sit side by side, bronzed and beautiful. NOW TRACKING PAST thick bush - the view from the Landrove it heads into deep country - The sound of CRASHING in the trees - An ELEPHANT lumbers out into the track just ahead, frighteningly close. The MOVING POV screeches to a halt. elephant continues across the track, followed by another, another. In the Landrover Diana sits very still, captivated by the sight. Robin has his camera out, taking photographs. The of elephants passes in front of and behind their vehicles thrillingly close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin and Diana are out walking in the bush with their friends COLIN CAMPBELL, Dr DON MCQUEEN, MARY DAWNAY and KATHERINE BARING, all young people of their own age. They're on the lookout for wild animals. Both Robin and C carry guns. The women walk behind. Robin is entranced by immense view.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: What is it you actually do out here, Robin?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I’m a tea broker. I get tea and I broke it. It’s very skilled work.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: And what does Diana do while you're off broking?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: She comes too.

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: My God! That’s almost indecent.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I like it. Really.

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: God gave men jobs to do so women could get a little time to themselves.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I like being with Robin. He's really quite bearable.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: I can’t see it myself. It’s alla mystery to me.

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: What Colin means is, how on earth did Robin manage to nab Diana?

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: Oh we’d all like to know that.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. How did you, darling?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: It’s very simple, really. Diana is bone idle. She hates having to make decisions. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathe - Salmon Revision - 26 July 2016 9aA.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She has no idea what she thinks about anything. So I tell her what to think, and I make all the decisions, and she’s happy as Larry. Right, darling?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: If you say so.  Breathe - Salmon Revision - 26 July 2016 9A-9B.

dialogues.speaker: 14B SCENE DELETED 14B
dialogues.text: Breathe - Salmon Revision - 26 July 2016 10. 14¢ EXT. NGONG HILLS, KENYA - EVENING 14c¢ The young people are gathered round a campfire in a grove fever trees, sharing a picnic supper. Diana lies with her head on Robin’s lap. Robin holds up his hand to ask for silence. Nothing but the sounds of dusk.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You hear that?

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: What? I don’t hear a thing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: That's just it. It’s like the dawn of creation.

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: The dusk of creation, you mean.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Watch out, Robin. Africa does funny things to people. (To Diana) Has he started talking to God?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Not exactly talking. But Robin and God are quite chummy.

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: You need faith to survive out here.

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: How can you say that, Don? And you a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: Oh, I believe in the power of the mind. Did you hear about the African prisoners on Kome Island? During the Mau-Mau rebellion? There were sixty of them crammed into a small tin hut. Prison officer wouldn’t let them out. The Mau-Mau leader said, very well, I give my men permission to die. Next morning all sixty were dead.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: Mind power. They chose to die. Turned their faces to the wall and died.  Breathe - Salmon Revision - 26 July 2016 10A.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: What a waste of mind power. I'd have chosen to live.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Quite right. Thats a sensible woman you've got there, Robin. Don’t lose her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I’ll try not to. He bends down and kisses her.  15

dialogues.speaker: 15A
dialogues.text: Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shady office of a tea warehouse. Drying tea plants ha over the windows, filtering the bright light. Diana sits fanning herself with a sales document at one end. Robin is inspecting the tea with a white ESTATE MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE MANAGER
dialogues.text: The Dark Amber is as good as you’ll get this year. Take a sniff of that. Robin smells the crumbled leaf. A black servant brings a of tea - pot and three cups - and sets it down beside Dia

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE MANAGER
dialogues.text: This one’s Milima Estate. More subtle fragrance, but it hasn’t got the depth. Robin smells the second type.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: What do you drink?

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Oh, I drink Nairobi Chai. But it’s too black for the home market. The Estate Manager crosses to the teapot beside Diana. He smells the tea in the pot, and pours.

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE MANAGER
dialogues.text: We don’t usually get wives on these buying trips, Mrs Cavendish.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: It’s Robin's business. I want to know about it.

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Secret of a happy marriage, eh? Never let hubby out of your sight. Diana blinks at this. The Estate Manager is quite unaware his crassness. He shows Robin the tea in the cup.

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE MANAGER
dialogues.text: You see the golden colour of the liquor? That’s top grade. Top price. Pure blonde.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Gentlemen prefer blondes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 11A.

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE MANAGER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry? To Robin’s amusement, Diana answers with a perfectly stra face -

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Diamonds are a girl’s best friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin and Diana driving back to Nairobi in their Landrove They sing as they go.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN/DIANA
dialogues.text: (singing) Time rolls on and youth is gone And you can’t straighten up when you bend -

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: (singing) But stiff back or stiff knees -

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (singing) You stand straight at Tiff’ny’s!

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN/DIANA
dialogues.text: (singing) Diamonds are a girl’s best friend! WIDE - The Landrover drives on as night descends.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’ve got news.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: It's a frightful bore. I shall never be able to have fun again. He throws a quick glance at her, worried.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’m going to have a baby. Robin slams on the brakes.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 11B. WIDE - The car has come to a stop by the side of the road it curves round an escarpment. Beyond, the vast expanse o Africa. IN THE CAR - Robin sits motionless for a moment. Then he turns to Diana, his face radiating happiness.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Somebody's pleased.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Very pleased?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Best news I’ve had since I proposed and you said yes.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You didn’t propose.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You said you had to get married before going out to Africa or you'd go native.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: But you did say yes, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Apparently I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 18 19 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A portable record player on the Landrover is playing a scratchy record: the song is ‘True Love’ from ‘High Socie Robin has Diana in his arms, and they’re dancing, alone o the high ridge, with the great view stretching out below in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: SINGER
dialogues.text: Sun-tanned Wind-blown Honeymooners at last alone Oh, how lucky we are! Robin and Diana are dancing slowly, smiling at each other Robin knows the words and anticipates the sung lines -

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I give to you -

dialogues.speaker: SINGER
dialogues.text: I give to you -

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: And you give to me -

dialogues.speaker: SINGER
dialogues.text: And you give to me -

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: True love -

dialogues.speaker: SINGER
dialogues.text: True love, true love So on and on It’ll always be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wide shaded terrace of a grand colonial building. Katherine Baring and Mary Dawnay dozing in the shade. Dia reading a novel. She’s now very pregnant. Governor EVELYN BARING comes out and stands on the terrac looking towards a distant tennis game.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN BARING
dialogues.text: Robin thrashing Colin again? His wife MOLLY BARING appears behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY BARING
dialogues.text: Come on. We’ll be late. They go. The thwack of tennis balls. Diana looks up to glimpse the distant game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin is playing tennis with Colin Campbell. He’s losing. Colin serves. Robin’s return hits the net.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Game! He throws his racket high into the air, whooping with triumph.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Hell of a serve, Col. I never knew you were that good.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: First game I’ve had off you in my life. How about one more?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: No. I’11 quit while I’m still standing. They leave the court.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: God, that feels good! So this is what it’s been like to be you all these years.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 14.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Enjoy it while it lasts, old chum. They come in sight of the lawn by the terrace, and burst into laughter. Katherine Baring and Mary Dawnay are attempting the latest craze - the hula hoop. Mary is good, swinging with her hips, making the hoop spi A small crowd of friends look on and applaud. Black servants grin from the terrace. Katherine is not so good. She steps out of her hoop as Robin and Colin join them.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE BARING
dialogues.text: God, I’m useless.

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: (swinging away) It’s all in the hips. Robin takes the dropped hoop and steps into it. Diana loo on, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: Robin’1l be a natural. You see. Robin spins the hoop, starts swinging his hips, but he can’t get the knack.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Harder than it looks.

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: Just imagine you’re jiving. Robin tries again. Diana looks on, smiling, one hand on h bump. Robin staggers slightly as he swings his hips. The hoop drops to the ground again.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Too much tennis. He turns to Diana. She’s not smiling any more: watching him, puzzled. He grins, moves towards her, gives his body shake as if to wake it up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I need a drink. Colin has picked up the abandoned hoop and is spinning it with great success.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: I’ve got it. It’s easy! Look at this! Robin! I’m doing it!  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 15. Robin turns to look, smiling. He feels his left arm with his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You all right, darling?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Yes, fine. So what’s the plan?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’ve asked Thomas to run me home. Don’s coming round to prod me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: (feeling his arm) Maybe he should give me a prod while he’s at it.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Are you sure you’re all right?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I think it’s got to me, watching you and your bump. Makes my joints ache.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I‘1l do my own aching, thank you very much. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: you get on home. I’ve got a meeting first thing. I’1l bunk here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plainly-furnished ADC’s bedroom. Robin sits on the bed pyjamas, feeling one arm. Sweat on his brow. He gets up and goes out into the passage. Knocks on a doo Colin Campbell appears in the doorway, woken from sleep.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Sorry, Col. I’m not feeling so good.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: You look ghastly.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: My arm is giving me gyp. Colin suddenly sees that Robin’s in intense pain.  23 24

dialogues.speaker: 240A
dialogues.text: Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin lies on a hospital bed surrounded by medical staff. Dr Don McQueen is running checks. Colin Campbell looks on from behind. Robin is now shivering with fever.

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: Lift your right arm. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: Left arm. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: Legs. Robin tries to move his legs and can’t. It’s scary.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Can’t move. What’s happening? His voice comes out with difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Can’t - breathe -

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: Get ice! CRUSHED ICE is packed round Robin’s body by nurses, movin fast. Robin lies, eyes open, breathing with difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: He’s losing it. We have to get him on a respirator. MOVING with Robin’s bed as it’s wheeled fast down a hospital corridor. Robin breathing in agonising wheezes. Don McQueen and Colin walking beside him.

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: Have to get oxygen into you somehow. Looks like we’re going to have to smash our way in.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE DELETED 24
dialogues.text: INT. NAIROBI HOSPITAL - NIGHT 24a CLOSE SHOT - A scalpel slices into Robin’s throat. The tracheotomy in action.  25 26 27 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIANA’S POV entering the ward - A bed with curtains round it. A large respirator beside it. The machine wheezes and clicks with a regular rhythm. The sound we've heard befor now identified. The nurse goes ahead of her and draws back the curtain. There lies Robin, on his back, with a tube coming out of his neck. The MOVING POV comes closer - goes round the bed - Robin lies utterly still but for his eyes, which strain t see. He looks just the same as ever, but for this spooky immobility.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Hello, darling. He looks back at her, unmoving.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Can I kiss him?

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: Yes. She bends over him, kisses him. Then she sits down by the bed. Her eyes have never left Robin's. His face twitches. His lips move: he’s trying to mouth words. Diana watches, pays close attention, begins to wor out what he’s saying.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: ‘Bit’ -

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: The air can’t reach the larynx any more. That’s why he can’t talk. Diana watches Robin’s lips: works it out.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: He says, ‘Bit of a bugger.’

dialogues.speaker: SCENE DELETED 27
dialogues.text: 28 29 Breathe - Pink Revision - 28 June 2016 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don McQueen stands at a chart showing a cutaway view of t body, explaining to Diana and Colin Campbell what has happened. Diana, very pregnant, sits on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: You inhale the virus from droplets in the air, the same way you catch a cold. It passes into the blood stream, into the central nervous system, and attacks a group of big cells in the spinal cord. The anterior horn cells. These are the cells that control the voluntary muscle system. The result is you become like a rag doll. You can’t move anything from the neck down. You can’t even breathe for yourself. He stops. Silence, while they take it in.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: How long will he be like this?

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: The paralysis is irreversible. A good respiration system will maintain life for a while. We're talking a matter of months. Diana takes this in in silence.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Does it affect his brain?

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: Not at all. Mentally he’s as alert as ever. He can move some facial muscles, as you've seen. His digestive system's unaffected. Diana looks up.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Can he feel me if I touch him?

dialogues.speaker: DON MCQUEEN
dialogues.text: Yes. He can still feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana sits beside Robin’s bed, one hand reached out. She’ stroking his face very slowly. He has his eyes closed.  30 31 Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 19. The machine hisses and clicks beside them. The tube carrying air to his throat twitches. ON DIANA - She’s not weeping. She’s just hurting so deepl she can hardly move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Governor, Evelyn Baring, and Colin Campbell, look on silence as Molly Baring sits with Diana, holding her hand

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY BARING
dialogues.text: Tell me what we can do. Diana can’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY BARING
dialogues.text: Do you want to go home?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: After the baby’s born.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY BARING
dialogues.text: What about Robin?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Him too.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY BARING
dialogues.text: You do know? She looks round to her husband to say what she can’t brin herself to say.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN BARING
dialogues.text: I’ve seen enough people paralysed by polio before. The mercy of it is, they don’t last long. Diana nods.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY BARING
dialogues.text: It’s no kind of life. Diana nods. Colin looks down. He can hardly bear this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON DIANA - Her head on a pillow, her eyes closed. She tur her head from side to side. Her face creases with pain. N sound. She seems to be asleep, perhaps having a bad dream Then her suffering intensifies. She bangs her head from side to side, her mouth opens in a silent scream, sweat glistens on her brow. It must be a hideous nightmare.  32 33 34 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 20. Then she jerks up, her eyes open, the pain unbearable. It bursts from her in a scream of agony.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Aaa-aaah! WIDE - Full sound. We now see we’re in a maternity ward i Nairobi. MIDWIVES and NURSES clustered round the bed. A pool of light on the lower part of the bed, obscured by their busy activity. A baby is being born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING POV tracking down the bright corridor as before, past the screens swaying in the breeze. Through doors and outer rooms. The MOVING POV enters Robin’s room and approaches his bed Robin gazes AT CAMERA. Diana holds the TINY BABY for him to see. The baby gazes back just as gravely at Robin. ON ROBIN - He gazes at the baby for a moment longer. Then he closes his eyes. Diana holds the baby against Robin’s unmoving cheek. A ki of contact for a moment. Then she takes him away. She watches Robin in silence. Kisses her baby’s cheek. No movement from Robin. His eyes stay closed. The respirator fills the silence with its hissing and clickin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TRANSPORT PLANE has just landed. The cargo doors are op and a tricky unloading operation is under way. Robin Cavendish is being hoisted out of the plane, strapped to stretcher. A big battery powered respirator is being unloaded alongside him. An ambulance waits to receive him Medics, RAF personnel and ground crew are gathered round.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: Easy now. Take it slowly. Keep some slack in the tube. That’s more like it. Down you come. They get the stretcher onto the tarmac. Now the respirato has to be man-handled into the ambulance.  35 36 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 21.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: (to Robin) Disconnecting you for a moment. ON ROBIN - The sound of the respirator ceases. He is no longer breathing. He takes it calmly, but for us the wait is unnerving. We hear the grunts and scrapes as the big respirator is heaved into the ambulance, and the sounds o wires being clipped back into place. Then Robin’s stretcher is on the move, into the ambulance The respirator starts up. The tube is replaced in his throat. Robin breathes again. His eyes close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana sits waiting with TID, her former nanny, called out retirement to help. A proud and capable woman. The pram stands between them. A young Pakistani doctor, DR KHAN, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: Mrs Cavendish?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry. This isn’t a good time. We’ve had to medicate your husband. Perhaps you could come back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I don’t mind if he’s asleep. I'd just like to see him.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: I don’t think it’s a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I don’t understand. The doctor hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: You know, with this sort of thing the morale can drop pretty low at times. Your husband is going through a temporary depression.  37 38 39 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 22.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I'd still like to see him.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. He doesn’t want to see you. Diana stares: shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin lies in his hospital bed, linked to his respirator. It hisses and clicks as it pumps away. SLOW MOVE IN on Robin. He lies with his eyes open, lookin up at nothing, tears seeping down his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana is on her way out of the hospital, with her baby in pram, accompanied by Tid.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’ll be able to manage from now on, Tid. It’s not fair to ask you to do this.

dialogues.speaker: TID
dialogues.text: I don’t see why not. I looked after you when you were a baby, didn’t I?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: The thing is, we’re not very well off, I’m afraid. We’ve got some savings, but there’s not a lot coming in.

dialogues.speaker: TID
dialogues.text: Don’t you worry about that. Your family’s my family, really. It’s nice to be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACK into the ward. Six beds, each one surrounded by medical apparatus, each one linked to a respirator, each one hissing and clicking as it pumps away. This sound, a syncopated rhythm of overlapping beats, fills the air. Diana’s brothers, Bloggs and David, sit on either side of Robin’s bed. Robin is laboriously mouthing words. Bloggs struggling to understand.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 23.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Sorry. I’m not being very clever here. Robin tries again. He’s mouthing three words. Bloggs catches the lips-together form of an M.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Mmm. ‘Mum’?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why would he say ‘mum’?

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Maybe he wants to see his mum.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (watching Robin) Ma? Moo? Me? Robin mouths ‘Yes’.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: ‘Me.’ Robin goes back to mouthing his three words.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Eh. Me. Aye.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Eh. ‘Get’ - is the first word “get'?

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Or ‘let’?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: ‘Let - me - lie’?

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: He is lying. Sorry, Robin. You must think we’re awful chumps. Robin mouths again. David suddenly gets it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: ‘Let me die.’ Robin closes his eyes, sinks back exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Let me die.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, that’s pretty bloody final, I must say.  40 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana walks through Oxford lanes with her brothers Bloggs and David. Students rattle past on bikes, dodging them as they go. Diana is putting on a good face, refusing to be sorry for herself.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Diana, darling. How can we help?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Oh, I shall manage.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: How are you off for money?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’ve got my share of what Mother left us. That'll keep us going for a while.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Talking to Robin was rather like one of those ghastly party games where you don’t know the rules.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: It was clever of you to get him to say anything at all. Bloggs comes to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: What he said was, ‘Let me die’. Diana meets Bloggs’s eyes. Giving nothing away.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Well, we can’t, can we? As they resume their progress down the lane -

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Do you mean we can’t even think such a thing, or we don’t know how to do it?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Both, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Makes no odds, really. I had a sort of a word with the Consultant. He wouldn't hear of it.  4l Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 25.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Not what they do.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: He said it’s not a good way to go. Several minutes of agony.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: No. I don’t want that.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: On the other hand, you have a life too.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: You are allowed to think of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana sits by Robin’s bed with her baby on her lap. Robin lies with his eyes open, but he’s not looking at either o them. The baby is fascinated by the rise and fall of the respirator.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: He couldn’t go on having no name. I decided to call him Jonathan. I hope that’s all right. No response from Robin. Diana watches him in silence. DR ENTWISTLE now joins them accompanied by his entourage, which includes Dr Khan. He checks his notes. Speaks in professionally cheerful tones.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: Well, Mrs Cavendish. We do have some progress to report.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Progress?

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: We're learning to swallow again.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: We are?

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: It’s more significant than it sounds. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 26.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At present we have an inflated cuff round our tracheotomy tube, to stop food or drink going down our windpipe. If we can swallow again, the cuff can be removed, and air can get to the larynx. Then we’ll be able to talk again. Diana takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Might there be other progress too?

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: This is about as good as it’s going to get, I’m afraid. (to Robin) How are we this morning? Robin stares back at him in silence.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: We wish we were dead. A twitch in Robin’s face. Was it a ghost of a smile?

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: (not listening) Good, good. Dr Entwistle moves on. He can be heard at the next bed, speaking breezily to another paralysed patient, PADDY. Paddy, a 40-year-old ex-soldier, is on a respirator like Robin.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: Good morning to you, Paddy. Ticking along as usual, I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana sits on a rug in this open quadrangle, an area of b grass, watching over baby Jonathan as he wriggles on his tummy beside her. Tid is pouring cups of tea for them fro Thermos flask. Diana’s face is turned away from us. Baby Jonathan manages a short burst of crawling.

dialogues.speaker: TID
dialogues.text: There’s a young lad who'll be on the move before we know it. Diana turns to her. Now we see the strain on her face.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 27.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: He never looks at him, Tid. He can’t bear even to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: TID
dialogues.text: You don’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. I know everything he’s thinking. Each time I go there I hope he’1l have changed. But he can’t bear to look at his own son.

dialogues.speaker: TID
dialogues.text: I loved my home, but when I left, I couldn’t turn and look back. I loved it too much.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Oh, Tid. The baby makes gurgling noises.

dialogues.speaker: TID
dialogues.text: There. Listen to him. He’ll be talking soon.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE DELETED 43
dialogues.text: 44 Breathe - Pink Revision - 28 June 2016 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON ROBIN - Seen through a gap in the curtains that surrou his bed. NURSE MARGARET, a smiley friendly young woman, i raising Robin in a hoist, removing a used bedpan, wiping bottom. Diana is on the other side of the curtains, watching ever move. Robin is lowered back onto his bed.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE MARGARET
dialogues.text: Let’s give you a suck, shall we? She takes the breathing tube out of Robin’s neck and inserts a suction tube. A glugging sound as the fluid in his lungs is drawn out into a container. Diana, watching, holds her breath. The breathing tube is re-inserted, and Robin breathes again. So does Diana. Nurse Margaret makes him tidy.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE MARGARET
dialogues.text: All comfy now? She pulls the curtains open. Paddy’s eyes follow the Nurs with admiration.  Breathe - Pink Revision - 28 June 2016 29. Diana moves forward so that she’s on Robin's eye-line.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: They tell me you’ve been learning to talk. Robin gazes at her. His lips move, preparing to talk. The slowly, slurring every growly word -—

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I'm... sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: That’s not what I want to hear.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You... are... so... lovely. Diana smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Better. Robin gazes at her a moment longer. Then his eyes close. Diana reaches out one hand and strokes his head, his face Just sits there stroking him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HOSPITAL CHAPLAIN is visiting Robin, sitting close, murmuring his professional consolations.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: An old priest I knew once, a very holy man, he used to say, ‘Those God loves most he allows to suffer most.’ Robin lies, eyes open, gazing up at the ceiling.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 30.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: We can’t know the mind of God. We can only know that whatever happens to us is somehow part of his plan. Robin makes a noise that might be a reply.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I missed that.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: (indistinct) Closer.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: What’s that you say?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Closer.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: Yes. Right. He moves his ear so that it’s near Robin’s lips. Robin spits in the Chaplain’s ear. It’s a feeble attempt a spit, but unmistakable. Paddy, in the next bed, sees it The Chaplain stands. He takes out a handkerchief, wipes h ear.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: Yes. Well. I’11 be moving on. He leaves Robin’s bedside, glancing round to see if anyon else saw what happened, and leaves. Paddy speaks so Robin can hear.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: That was grand. Robin can see Paddy out of the corner of his eye. He rais one eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: I’m thinking you’re not a believer.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Believer in what?... God’s a joke.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: No, pal. God's a joker. Look at the pig’s mickey he’s made of you and me. Robin grins at that.  48 49 50 51 52 Breathe - Double White - 18 August 2016 31.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: How do you live like this?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: You get used to it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: What if I don’t?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: There’s always a way out. He indicates the empty bed opposite.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Like Pete there got out. His own private box.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE DELETED 49
dialogues.text: INT. WARD, OXFORD HOSPITAL/ROBIN’S BEDROOM, GOVERNMENT 50

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP ON ROBIN - In bed, apparently in Oxford Hospital PULL BACK TO REVEAL - Robin in the bedroom at Government House where he became ill. PULL BACK FURTHER - He has a tube running into a throat tracheotomy. Robin awakes, looks confused, pulls out his tube, leans forward and looks out, desperately in search Diana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBIN’S POV - A window is curtain drawn back. Bright ligh of day. Out of the brightness the image of Diana forms. She’s come to visit him. For a few moments he gazes at her in silence.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Why do you keep on coming? Diana doesn’t answer at once. It’s a fair question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  Breathe - Pink Revision - 28 June 2016 31A.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I don’t really know.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 32.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I’m no damn use to you... You should leave me to rot.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: It wouldn’t look very good. Robin twitches a smile at that.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: And apparently I love you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Not this... You can’t love this.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Apparently I can.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to... It makes it harder for me.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yes. I can see that. You’d rather just pack it in, I know.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Bloody machine keeps on breathing for me.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: So it looks as if you’re going to have to stick around for a while.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’m not sorry. I’d like Jonathan to know you. His face twitches. She scratches the itch for him.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: And maybe I can make life a little better for you. He looks at her. She strokes his face and head.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: It’s only duty.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yes, all right. We know all about that. Everything is as bad as it could be. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 Breathe - Goldenrod Revision - 11 July 2016 33-

dialogues.speaker: DIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I can’t go on coming in here and have you saying you wish you were dead. You’re not dead, and that’s that. Robin stares at her. This is a new Diana.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: There must be something I can do to make things more bearable. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Get me out of here. He knows it’s impossible as he says it. But Diana’s thinking: Maybe that’s the only way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana stands outside a big crumbling house, gazing at it dismay. Beside her stands its owner, MR TOLLAND, an elder man as decrepit as the house.

dialogues.speaker: MR TOLLAND
dialogues.text: I’ll be sad to go, of course, after all these years. But since Muriel died I can’t seem to get on top of things. Things can run away with you, you know.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: It needs a lot of work. Is the roof sound? Mr Tolland casts a melancholy eye on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: MR TOLLAND
dialogues.text: Some of it.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Why are some of the windows bricked up?

dialogues.speaker: MR TOLLAND
dialogues.text: Ah,yes. Those are my rooms, you see. Muriel said it saved so much on the heating bills. Diana gazes up at the unpromising prospect. Then she draw deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: It’s a lot of work, but I think it might just about do. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathe - Goldenrod Revision - 11 July 2016 33-

dialogues.speaker: DIANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t pay twelve thousand, of course. Or anywhere near.

dialogues.speaker: MR TOLLAND
dialogues.text: I'd take eleven. Or even ten.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: All I can manage is seven.

dialogues.speaker: MR TOLLAND
dialogues.text: Seven?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Cash. And you’d be rid of the place for ever. And Muriel. Mr Tolland’s face creases into a slow smile.

dialogues.speaker: 53A SCENE DELETED 53A
dialogues.text: Breathe - Goldenrod Revision - 11 July 2016 33A. 54 INT. DR ENTWISTLE’S OFFICE, OXFORD HOSPITAL - DAY 54 Diana sits facing the Dr Entwistle, who is enthroned behi his desk.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it’s out of the question. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Has anyone tried?  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 34.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: No one with your husband’s degree of disability, anywhere in the world, exists outside a hospital. Diana seems not to be taking this in.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’ve watched what the nurses do. If we can have a respirator at home I don’t see why it wouldn't work. Dr Entwistle tries to control his irritation.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: Allow me to explain. Your husband is only alive because a machine is breathing for him. If that machine should fail, in under two minutes your husband would be dead. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: Forgive me if I speak plainly. Have I made myself clear?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin is speaking to Paddy in a low voice.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: She’s up to something... She’s scheming.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: So what's her plan?... Dig a tunnel for you to escape? Dr Khan and Nurse Margaret enter. Robin and Paddy fall silent. Nurse Margaret comes to Paddy’s bedside.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE MARGARET
dialogues.text: How are you, Paddy? Let’s make you comfortable, shall we?  Breathe - Pink Revision - 28 June 2016 35. She places a urine bottle for him. He starts to pee. A lo of ecstasy on his face.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Aah! Pissing... Best moment of the day. Dr Khan checks Robin's charts. Diana enters and comes to Robin’s bedside. She gives Robi kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Morning, darling. Dr Khan gives her a nod as he continues with his checks.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: Mrs Cavendish. Nurse Margaret is now preparing to suck the fluid from Robin’s lungs. Diana looks on.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Do you think I could do that?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE MARGARET
dialogues.text: I don’t see why not. It’s just like a Hoover, really.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 35A. Diana watches as Nurse Margaret switches off the respirat pump, removes the breathing tube, and inserts the suction tube.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE MARGARET
dialogues.text: Here, give it a try. Hold it like this. Diana holds the tube. Nurse Margaret switches on the pump The tube gives a jerk, and fluid gloops out. Diana jumps, unnerved.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Oh God! Please! Take it! Dr Khan grins: it’s as he expected. Nurse Margaret takes over. Diana watches the rest of the process closely.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Once I got used to it, I think I could manage.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: Why would you want to manage, Mrs Cavendish?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Robin?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Robin and I wanted to ask you, Dr Khan. Can machines like that - (the respirator) - only work in hospitals?

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: Well, it’s just a machine, you know. You plug it in and it goes. Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Robin’s going to leave the hospital. Dr Khan is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: Impossible!

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I think you mean inadvisable.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: You do have any idea of the risk?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yes. The risk is he might die.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 35AaA. The sucking is completed. The breathing tube goes back in Robin can speak again. Diana turns to him.  Breathe - Pink Revision - 28 June 2016 35DA.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Robin?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I go on living here like this... Or I leave here and die.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: What are we waiting for?  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloggs and David stagger down the stairs with a bed.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, you halfwit! Up! I said up!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: But we’re going down.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lift your end UP to get the bloody thing DOWN!  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 37. They manoeuvre the bed into the study.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Left! LEFT!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I am going left!

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Then go right! They get the bed into the study.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Further over. We have to leave room for Robin’s bed. Once it’s in place, they both sit down on it, side by sid and mop their brows. Through the French windows little Jonathan can be seen ou the garden with Tid. He’s playing with a terrier puppy, BENJY.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Diana sleeps in this bed?

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: And Robin’s bed comes here? He indicates the space they’ve left beside it.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: That’s what she wants.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Surely Robin’1l have a nurse.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: No nurse. Just Diana.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What about - I mean - she can’t be with him every minute of the day and night. She has to pee. Tid speaks from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: TID
dialogues.text: She’s got me.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE DELETED 58
dialogues.text: Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ward in darkness. The sounds of the respirators form weave of hissing in the wider silence. ON ROBIN - His eyes are open, gazing up at nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Five pounds says you'll never make it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: What do I get if I do?

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: You get five.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You’re on. Other patients in the ward overhear them.

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT 1
dialogues.text: Thinks he’s getting out.

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT 2
dialogues.text: Some chance.

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT 1
dialogues.text: Bloody nutter!

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT 2
dialogues.text: Like taking candy from a baby. Paddy whispers conspiratorially at Patient 2 -

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Hush up and I’11 cut you in on my winnings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 Breathe - Pink Revision - 28 June 2016 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr Khan and Diana enter the ward, followed by Nurse Marga They head for Robin’s bed. Dr Khan’s looking round nervou The other patients are all watching with interest.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (to Robin) This is it.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: (to Robin) I’m only permitting this because your wife has taken full responsibility for the consequences. You can still change your mind.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I want to go.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: Very well. (to Nurse) You ready? Nurse Margaret nods. Dr Khan shifts Robin’s respirator to trolley. Nurse Margaret unlocks the bed’s wheels.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Best of luck, pal.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: So long, Paddy. I’1ll be back for my fiver. Paddy watches as Robin’s bed is wheeled away.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: I'll miss you, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rumbling sound. Double doors open. Diana peeps out to s if the coast is clear. The doors open wide to let ROBIN’S HOSPITAL BED through, pushed by Nurse Margaret. Beside hi rolls the respirator on a trolley, pushed by Dr Khan. Dia walks by the side of the bed, one hand on Robin’s arm.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 39A. The procession passes through another set of double doors There ahead a grim figure looms into view. Dr Entwistle.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 40. The bed and the trolley come to a stop under his witherin stare.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: Where do you think you’re going?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: We're taking my husband home.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: You don’t have my permission.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Is this a prison?... Am I your prisoner? Dr Entwistle doesn’t register Robin at all. He addresses Khan.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: What do you think you’re doing?

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: It’s the patient’s own wish, sir. He’s fully apprised of the risks.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: Is the patient medically qualified? Take him back to the ward at once.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Diana. Call the police... Tell them I’m being held against my will. Now Dr Entwistle takes in Robin’s living presence.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I’m neither criminal nor insane... You have no right to stop me leaving this place. A long beat. Dr Entwistle looks from Robin to Diana and back again. He’s very angry, but hides it under sarcastic courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: Of course. Be my guest. Do as you please. He stands aside. The procession rolls past.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: You'll be dead in two weeks.  61 62 63 Breathe - Yellow Revision - 5 July 2016 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjy on a lead held by Tid, with little Jonathan by her side. Beside them, Colin Campbell, Bloggs Blacker and Har Tennyson. A welcome committee for the ambulance as it pul up to Furlongs. The ambulance men roll Robin out of the ambulance. Benjy yaps. Jonathan watches eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: How’s Robin coping?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: So far, so good. Robin is disconnected from the respirator in the ambulanc and stretchered into the house. He looks round him as he goes. ROBIN’S POV - Grey stone walls. Glimpses of garden. Littl Jonathan pointing at him, moving alongside him. Benjy bouncing and yapping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin is carried down the hall and into his new room. Her the ambulance men lift him onto a hospital bed, now place beside the other bed. Diana inserts the breathing tube attached to the new respirator. Robin breathes again. A tense few moments is over.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Are you all right, darling?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Yes... Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: It actually works?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: It works. Bloggs and Harry shake hands. Diana, Colin, Bloggs and Harry gather round the bed.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 42.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: This is it. Our new home. Robin looks round as best as he can, rolling his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Better. Colin is inspecting the respirator.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: What happens if there’s a power cut?

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: You work it with a hand pump.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Nifty bit of kit. Tid, Jonathan and Benjy come in. Diana picks Jonathan up he can see Robin.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: There’s Daddy. Little Jonathan gazes at Robin. Robin gazes back. The fir time he’s acknowledged his existence.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Hello, Jonathan. Benjy jumps up onto the bed. He sniffs at Robin, and give a little bark. Robin ‘barks’ back. Jonathan bursts into laughter. Robin smiles. His first proper smile.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE DELETED 64
dialogues.text: 65 66 67 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 43. INT. ROBIN’S ROOM, FURLONGS - NIGHT 65 Robin lies in the darkness with his eyes open. The wheeze and clank of the breathing machine. WIDEN to see the second bed alongside his bed. Here Diana lies, settling down to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Good night, darling.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Good night. Diana’s hand reaches out and feels its way to his face. S strokes his brow and cheeks and lips. He kisses her finge She leans across and touches her lips to his.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE DELETED 66
dialogues.text: INT. ROBIN’S ROOM, FURLONGS - DAY 67 JONATHAN'S POV - Crossing the room towards his father’s b looming above him. Peering at the fascinating machine by bed, that hisses to itself. Jonathan mimics the machine’s wheezing sound. Benjy comes trotting in. Jonathan tries to take Benjy in arms but the dog wriggles free. Jonathan topples over, tr to get him back. As he scrabbles about on the floor he pu unknowingly on the power cord. The respirator stops. Robin, helpless in bed, makes a clicking noise in his mou his distress signal. Jonathan, entirely unaware of the crisis, chases after Be Dog and child run out of the room. Robin’s eyes show his mounting fear. He keeps making the clicking noise. He can hear the radio playing in the kitc A squeal of pain from Jonathan in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jonathan! Are you all right? The seconds are passing. Robin's eyes close. He stops mak his noise. Diana’s footsteps in the hall. Jonathan whimpering.  68 69 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 44,

dialogues.speaker: DIANA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s just a bump. No damage done. Here, I'll kiss it better. Now at last she comes into Robin’s room.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Robin - Oh my God! She races for the machine, finds the plug, pushes it back The regular hissing begins again. Robin opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry. I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: That was interesting.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: How did it happen?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Jonathan... Fell over... Just an accident. She puts out one hand, still shaky from the shock, to str his cheek. The distant roar of an engine -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pale blue Mercedes convertible sweeps across the lawn i front of the house. IN CAR - The driver is a big genial eccentric, TEDDY HALL On the passenger seat beside him in a cardboard box six bottles of wine rattle and clink. INT. ROBIN’S BEDROOM, FURLONGS - DAY 69 Teddy Hall works a corkscrew into a bottle of wine. Colin Campbell lights two candles on a birthday cake. There’s a small party happening round Robin’s bed. Diana has little Jonathan on her lap in his best clothes, while Tid looks Friends from Kenya are here: Mary Dawnay and Katherine Baring. And of course Bloggs and David Blacker.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: Best claret I’ve got. Spent the war in my air raid shelter. POP! Out comes the cork. Teddy Hall fills the glasses he’ also brought with him.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 45.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Looks like a good drop, Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: It is good. Good wine deserves good glasses. He gives Diana a glass -

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: For the lovely Diana. And glasses for the others.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: Mary. Katherine. Bloggs. David. Tid? Tid shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: TID
dialogues.text: No, no, not for me.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Tid only drinks Dubonnet.

dialogues.speaker: TID
dialogues.text: And only on my birthday. Diana arranges Robin’s glass with a straw that he can reach. Teddy raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: To Jonathan. Happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: To Jonathan. ON LITTLE JONATHAN - Gazing back, enjoying the attention.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (to Jonathan) Now you blow out the candles. She helps Jonathan blow out the candles. They all clap. Jonathan claps. Diana starts cutting up the cake. Teddy Hall studies the respirator. Robin sips wine through a straw.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I wonder what it would be like to get drunk... given that I’m legless already.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 45A.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: What you have to do with mechanical devices is stress-test them. Find their breaking point.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Interesting experiment, Teddy. Of course, Robin would die. But you’d probably be able to improve the machine.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 46.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: All progress has its price. Teddy Hall is too intrigued by the machine to hear this.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: The weak link is the power supply. Power can fail. Power frequently fails.

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: Do stop it, Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: Just hypothesising.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: It is his job.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He’s an Oxford professor. He hasn’t got a job.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: There’s nothing to worry about. It can be worked by hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: What about in the night?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE BARING
dialogues.text: But you have to sleep some time.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: If Robin needs me, he wakes me.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: He makes this noise, like a duck. He makes a quacking sound.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: More like a chicken. He makes a clucking sound. Robin makes his own clicking noise in his mouth. They all look at him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Not much, is it? I'd rather have a bell. He sees Teddy Hall watching him closely.  70 71 72 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 47.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: What can you move? Robin moves everything that moves: mouth, tongue, eyebrow

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: You can move your head. I’ve seen you do it. Teddy holds his palms on either side of Robin’s head.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: Move your head. Robin moves his head. It’s such a small move it’s almost invisible.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: I think I can have some fun with that. INT. TEDDY HALL’S WORKSHOP - DAY 70 The large workshop is cluttered with machine tools, parts of clocks, electrical devices, and all sorts of litter. I the midst of all this, Teddy Hall is at work bodging up a padded lever connected to a bell. He’s setting its sensitivity, making it so that a very slight pressure rin the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Jonathan races round and round the lawn, chased by Benjy. Tid sits on a garden chair reading a detective novel. Jonathan’s push chair stands empty beside her. Jonathan charges up to the French windows to Robin’s room and presses his face to the window panes. He bangs on the glass. INT. ROBIN’S ROOM, FURLONGS - DAY 72 Jonathan’s cheery little face outside the window, smiling and banging. The eternal wheeze and clank of the respirator. Robin is in bed, studying stock prices, the Financial Tim open on a rack before him. A heap of old copies of the Financial Times lies on the floor. He hears Jonathan banging and smiles for him. Then he winces. He moves his head. We now see Teddy Hall’s apparatus fixed to the bedhead enables him to sound a bel Diana appears.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 48.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Bottle?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Please. Diana takes a cloth-covered glass urine bottle from a table, draws back Robin's bedclothes, and carefully arranges him so he can relieve himself. We hear the sound as he pees.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You know the Marconi shares I bought?... Justin’s hot tip... They've almost doubled in price.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I hope Justin gets something out of it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Of course he does... He gets the agreeable sensation of having helped... someone less fortunate than himself.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Poor Robin, paralysed for life.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: And his poor wife. I hear she’s a saint. They grin at each other a little guiltily: making fun of other people’s pity. A squeal of laughter outside, a burst of yapping. Robin looks out of the French windows. ROBIN’S POV - Jonathan has got hold of his push chair. He pushing it busily up and down the terrace, followed by Benjy. He finishes peeing. Diana removes the bottle, straightens the bed, heads for the door. Robin watches little Jonathan racing his push chair on th terrace.  73 74 75 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 49.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Call Teddy, darling... I’ve had an idea. INT. TEDDY HALL’S WORKSHOP - DAY 73 CLOSE ON a metal frame onto which has been bolted an electric motor and a bellows. A bicycle chain links the two. Wires run to a 12 volt battery. Teddy connects the leads and the motor turns. The chain drives, and the bellows rise and fall. A few turns and the chain falls off.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: Bugger. CLOSE SHOTS - The motor’s position is adjusted - the chai is tightened. An aircraft seat is bolted on. Wheels for t contraption come off a bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a record player as the pick-up arm descends on a spinning LP. The SOUND OF TRUMPETS: the Grand March from Aida.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The French windows to Robin’s room are wide open. To the sound of the Grand March, out comes a strange procession. It's led by Robin, seated in a home-made WHEELCHAIR with battery-operated pump. Teddy Hall pushes the chair. Diana walks alongside, watching closely to see that Robin's breathing tube stays in, and that the pump keeps pumping. It makes a gentler sound than the static respirator. Tid and Jonathan and Benjy follow behind. On the terrace a small crowd of friends applaud: Bloggs a David, Colin Campbell, Mary Dawnay, Katherine Baring, Har Tennyson. ON ROBIN - Looking a little alarmed at being lurched abou but thrilled to bits. The procession marches round the terrace to the stirring sound of Verdi’s trumpets, and comes to a stop in the mid of the crowd of smiling friends.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: There’1l be no stopping him now.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 50.

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: It's terrifying. What if it breaks? Diana and Teddy Hall study the respirator. It still seems to be working.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (to Robin) How does it feel?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: A little fast?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Perhaps a little. Teddy clicks the lever on the bicycle gears that regulate the chain. The machine pumps a little more slowly.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: Better?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: How long will the battery last?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: Up to three hours, we think.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY TENNYSON
dialogues.text: Isn’t this a case where a little more certainty would be appropriate?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: There’s a mains lead too.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Teddy. You're a genius.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: To be honest it all turned out to be pretty basic. I used a bicycle chain and Sturmey Archer gears. I don’t know why it hasn’t been done before.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Because you’re not a doctor... There’s no one to tell you it can’t be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana wheels Robin in his wheelchair into the hospital lo

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: We have an appointment with Dr Khan. Robin Cavendish, for his check-up. IN HALLWAY - Diana wheels Robin down a hallway and into a ward. This is the same ward from which he escaped, still occupied by many of the same paralysed patients on respirators. As Diana wheels Robin between the beds, the patients stare. Some are amazed, but some look confused, distressed. Robin’s former neighbour Paddy is grinning al over his face. Beside him stands Nurse Margaret, also loo on in wonder. Robin says to Diana -

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Take me to Paddy... Hey, Paddy!

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Robin!... You jammy little beggar! Dr Khan comes into the ward and sees the wheelchair. He approaches, his face filled with admiration.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: This is really quite something! Dr Entwistle enters, and stares at them in frigid silence advances towards them, turning his anger on Dr Khan, as i Robin and Diana aren't there.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: Did you give permission for this contraption to be brought into my ward? Dr Khan starts to answer, but Dr Entwistle isn’t interest in any excuses.

dialogues.speaker: DR ENTWISTLE
dialogues.text: It’s hard enough for our patients to accept the conditions of their lives without raising false hopes that can only leave them more dissatisfied. Where you come from it may be common practice to play games with people’s lives, but here it is not. Is that understood? He stalks off out of the ward.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 51a.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: The man’s a pompous idiot... Don’t you want to smack him?

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: Believe me, I’m used to it.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 52.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You'd think he’d want to get wheelchairs like this for his other patients.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: (to Paddy) Paddy, you owe me a fiver.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Not so fast, pal... You could drop off your perch tomorrow. (to Dr Khan) How safe is it, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Paddy. It’s the first time I’ve seen anything like it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: (to Paddy) Does four miles an hour with... the wind behind you. Dr Khan is examining the wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: (to Paddy) I'd advise waiting a little while longer. Test its limits.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Quite right... Find the breaking point.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: We're not testing Robin till he breaks.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Yes, we are... That’s exactly what we're doing.

dialogues.speaker: DR KHAN
dialogues.text: Let’s get on with this check-up, shall we? See what state you’re in. As Diana wheels Robin away to an examination room, follow by Dr Khan, Paddy speaks to Nurse Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: If he doesn’t make it, who pays me my fiver?

dialogues.speaker: 75C
dialogues.text: 76 Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana wheels Robin back out onto the street.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You're doing better than all his other patients. That’s what he said.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Poor old Paddy... I wish we could help him to escape too. Two PASSING WOMEN pause to stare at Robin. They assume he neither see nor hear them.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST WOMAN
dialogues.text: It isn’t kind to let them out like that.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND WOMAN
dialogues.text: On the street, where everyone can see.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Believe me, ladies... My distress is greater than yours. The women hurry on their way, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST WOMAN
dialogues.text: Did he speak? Was that him speaking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JONATHAN'S POV - MOVING THROUGH sun-dappled bushes in the depths of the garden towards a light-filled gap - and there, across the wide lawn, sits Robin on the terrace in his wheelchair, Benjy curled up on his lap. Beside him si Tid, reading her book. LITTLE JONATHAN, now aged 5, is exploring the fringe of t pond. The phone rings: an amplified external ringer. Jonathan w at his father.

dialogues.speaker: TID
dialogues.text: (to Robin) Should I answer that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. I'll be fine.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 53aA. Tid rises, puts down her book, and goes into the house.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 53A. Jonathan moves closer to the shore of the pond. A flicker of light as a fish flashes through the water. Fascinated, Jonathan looks closer. Across the lawn, Robin is watching, calling something we' almost too far away to hear.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Jonathan! Be careful! Jonathan turns back to look at his father - and slips on the pond’s verge - and tumbles into the water. ON ROBIN - Horrified. ROBIN’S POV - The place where Jonathan had been standing, now empty. The distant sound of splashing. Distant cries. ON ROBIN - Helpless, frozen. Then he comes to his senses and presses at his bell. The bell rings on his wheelchair  77 78 Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 54. Tid comes running out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Jonathan. Pond. Tid runs to the pond. Benjy jumps off Robin’s lap and follows her. Robin watches as she pulls Jonathan out of t water. He hears his screams, at their most intense now he is safe. Tid carries the soaking screaming child back.

dialogues.speaker: TID
dialogues.text: He’s all right. He’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: My fault... I’m sorry. ON ROBIN - Gazing at his frightened screaming son. Overwhelmed with the awareness of his own powerlessness. INT. ROBIN AND DIANA’S BEDROOM, FURLONGS - NIGHT 77 Jonathan enters in his pyjamas, all alone. Comes to Robin bedside.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Come to say goodnight?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Sorry, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You must be careful, you know. Jonathan nods, gazingly solemnly back at him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Don’t want any accidents... Don’t want you hurt.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
