dialogues.text: Don’t want you hurt. The little boy reaches out one hand and strokes his father’s face. He’s imitating what he’s seen his mother d so many times. Robin smiles, very touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's winter, and very cold in the drafty old house. Ice o the windowpanes. Robin is wrapped in blankets in his wheelchair, and wears a hat and mittens. Diana, also well wrapped, is carrying out the chore of sucking the fluid f his lungs.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 54aa. She’s so used to this now that she can talk while she wor Robin of course can’t speak, his breathing suspended unti she’s done.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 54a.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Bloggs told me the other day that all our friends were convinced I'd give up on you. Apparently they saw me as some kind of pampered nitwit.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 55. She finishes and reinstates the breathing tube.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You were a pampered nitwit.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Didn't stop you running after me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I’ve got nothing against nitwits... so long as they’re pretty.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Well, you’re stuck with me now.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Just think... All those affairs I could have had.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: And me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: It’s not too late.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: What, and come back to find you've popped off while I’m out?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Yes, that would rather spoil the party. JONATHAN comes in, now FIVE YEARS OLD, carrying a photogr album. He too is well wrapped.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Look! I found Daddy! CLOSE SHOTS of black-and-white photographs in an album: pictures of Robin in uniform, surrounded by friends from regiment, the Greenjackets. Diana goes to look at the album.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: That’s Daddy when he was a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Daddy’s a soldier! He turns the page. Now the photographs show Diana and Rob in Kenya, surrounded by elephants.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: This is us in Africa, where you were born.  79

dialogues.speaker: T9A
dialogues.text: Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 56-57. Jonathan doesn’t even notice the contrast between his father then and now. He likes the wild animals.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Wow! Elephants! You saw elephants! ON DIANA - Finding it painful to look at the pictures. Sh looks up and meets Robin’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: You were luck-ee-ee. He settles down on the floor, absorbed by the photographs Diana leaves Jonathan looking at the album, and returns t Robin. She’s smiling but she has tears in her eyes. She b down to kiss him. Her tears slightly moisten his cheek. S brushes the wetness from his face.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I wish I could go to Africa.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Do you, darling? She goes on gazing down at Robin. She mouths silently to Sorry. He mouths back: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I'd better sort out tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana puts on the kettle, and then stands by the kitchen table, holding it as if to steady herself, and closes her eyes. Sometimes it just feels too hard. She hears the voices coming faintly from the drawing room

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can we go to Africa, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That would be fun.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I could push you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Rather a long way to push me.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t mind.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 56A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana carries the tea tray in. Jonathan goes for the cake once. As Diana pours tea for herself and Robin -

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: This chair pushing... Just how hard is it, over a long distance?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Harder than a pram, I can tell you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: (to Jonathan) Well, Jonathan... We’re going to have to do some more thinking.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE DELETED 80
dialogues.text: 81 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON ROBIN - Grinning as he rises slowly upwards. He’s in his wheelchair, which is on the powered tail-gate a converted Bedford van. The MECHANIC who has built it is showing Robin and Diana how it works.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: As per your design, Mr Cavendish. Takes up to three hundred pounds. The tail-gate reaches the van’s floor level. The mechanic rolls Robin and his chair into the back of the van, and closes the rear doors.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: (to Diana) Hydraulic lifting mechanism. You won’t see that on a Bedford anywhere else. IN THE VAN - Robin looks round the enclosed space. Outside, the mechanic repeats the process in reverse. Rob is wheeled back out.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: (proud) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: It’s wonderful... But it has a design fault.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: It’s rather dark in the back... It makes me feel like luggage.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: (taken aback) I just thought - being as the wheelchair has to be got in - the back seemed... His voice falters under Robin’s steady gaze.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Have you ever sat in the back of the van?

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: Me? Well, no. But then I’m not - I’m not -  82 Breathe - Salmon Revision - 26 July 2016 59.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Luggage? (Beat) Please don’t think I’m not grateful... I suppose it has to be this way.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: You want to sit in the front?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Would it be very difficult to arrange?

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: I suppose if I took our the front seat... He’s peering at the space in the front, working out how i could be done.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You’ve done such marvellous work on the tail lift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH ANGLE - Down the road comes the Bedford van. IN THE VAN - Diana driving. And beside her, in the passenger seat space, Robin in his wheelchair. The slidin door is open beside him, the wind blowing in his hair. Jonathan sits behind with Benjy. The respirator hisses away, drawing its power from the car battery. Robin loves the open spaces, the wind, the freedom. He starts to sing in his croaky voice -—

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: When I get to heaven... tie me toa tree... For I’ll begin to roam and soon... You'll know where I will be... Diana and Jonathan laugh and join in as he sings.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 59A.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN/DIANA/ JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I was bo-orn... Under a wand’rin’ star... A wand’rin’, wand’rin’ star... CRANE UP to see the road and a wide view of the surroundi countryside as the Bedford van drives on.

dialogues.speaker: 84B
dialogues.text: 85 Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some years have passed. It’s now 1970. A crowd of friends fills the garden. JONATHAN, NOW TEN YEARS OLD, is playing cricket in the field beside the garden with a mix of his friends and older guests. A ring of small girls holds a dolls’ tea party, watched by Tid. Bloggs Blacker is by the terrace table, hacking at a ham, 84

dialogues.speaker: 84B
dialogues.text: 85 talking to Teddy Hall. David Blacker carries plates of fo to guests, among them Colin Campbell and RORY STEWART, a good-looking man in his 40s. We follow the party in a montage of brief moments.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE TERRACE TABLE -
dialogues.text: Bloggs, carving the ham, glancing over towards Robin.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: He’s amazing, isn’t he?  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 Teddy Hall's looking at Diana.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: So’s she. 61. BY ROBIN IN HIS WHEELCHAIR listening to Rory Stewart -

dialogues.speaker: RORY STEWART
dialogues.text: Lucy walked out a month ago now. Been coming a long time.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Rory... Very rough on you.

dialogues.speaker: RORY STEWART
dialogues.text: Yes. Life’s a shitty business, isn’t it? There you are, getting on with your life, and out of nowhere - crash! It all comes tumbling down.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: And you know what’s so strange?... The sun still comes up tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: RORY STEWART
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing really... Help me with my drink, will you, Rory. Rory moves Robin’s glass near enough for Robin to reach t straw with his lips.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Let’s have a toast.

dialogues.speaker: RORY STEWART
dialogues.text: What are we drinking to?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: New dawns. Rory raises his own glass, smiling for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: RORY STEWART
dialogues.text: New dawns! AT THE DOLLS’ TEA PARTY -

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: Rosie says, It’s been delightful, but I simply must rush. THE GAME OF CRICKET -— Diana with Colin Campbell watching Jonathan as he bowls.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 61A.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I think he’s going to be quite good. BY THE TERRACE TABLE — Harry Tennyson is shovelling food in liberal quantities o his plate.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY TENNYSON
dialogues.text: You really should go to Simla, it’s not like India at all. You’re in the Himalayas, but it feels like England. Like England, but better. The Blacker twins surveying the ruin of the ham carved by Bloggs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You’ve made a real hash of that.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Look at Robin now. They both look. Robin has four pretty women round him now

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: How does he do it?  86 87 Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 62. BY ROBIN IN HIS WHEELCHAIR - One of the pretty women, PAM HARRIS, confiding in him.

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA HARRIS
dialogues.text: He proposed yesterday. I’m so fond of him. But he’s no beauty. I feel so confused.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Is he actually ugly?

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA HARRIS
dialogues.text: Well, yes. As they speak, Robin’s looking across the lawn to where D stands, in conversation with Rory Stewart. From their bod language he can see that Rory’s confiding in her, and she being sympathetic.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA HARRIS
dialogues.text: Why’s that good?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Good-looking men are idle... Ugly men get things done.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAME OF CRICKET -
dialogues.text: Jonathan, batting, hits the ball a terrific whack, sendin sailing into the shrubbery. He tosses his bat in the air, turns triumphantly to call to his father.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Dad! You see that? Robin is gazing at him, full of pride. Diana, sitting bes Robin, shares the proud moment: her hand applauds, clappi softly on Robins’ hand, as if they’re clapping together.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE DELETED 86
dialogues.text: INT. ROBIN’S ROOM, FURLONGS - EVENING 87 The party’s over. The guests departed. Diana comes into the room where Robin sits in his bed. Sh tends to him, arranging him to make him comfortable, befo going to bed herself.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: So. Did you enjoy that? You were surrounded by admirers.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 62A.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: So were you.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 63.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Rory Stewart couldn’t take his eyes off you.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Oh, Rory. Lucy’s really messed him about. I feel so sorry for him. He says he spends his evenings alone, watching television.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I expect he’d like you to relieve his loneliness.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not going to.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You can if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Oh. You’re giving me permission, are you?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I worry that you don’t have much... fun.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about me. I’m all right. She strokes his head lovingly.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: We manage, don’t we?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Easy for me... I just sit here... You do all the work... Turns out I’m quite enjoying myself.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (fondly) Good old selfish Robin.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 63A.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: But you... Not so much fun for you. She bends down and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Turns out I love you. He responds to her kiss. The loving nuzzling of his lips moves her, almost too much. Her eyes glisten.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I got lucky with you, didn’t I?... I say, Diana. Run away with me.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Mustn’t overdo it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Why not?... I’m supposed to be testing the limits.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You are. Every day.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Haven’t reached breaking point yet, have I?... I can go further.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Go further where?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Anywhere... Everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: What is this, Robin? Is this another of your mad projects?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I’ve always wanted to see the sun rise over the Mediterranean.  88 89 90 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front wheels of the van riding up a long ramp. PULL OUT TO DISCOVER the cargo hold of a front-opening transport plane, as the Bedford van disappears into its belly. IN THE VAN - Diana at the wheel. Robin beside her in his wheelchair. Behind them, Jonathan and Bloggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cargo plane rumbles down the runway and creaks into t sky. THE CAMERA follows it up into the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the Bedford van, in the hold of the cargo plane: everything is juddering, the engine noise is unbearable, there they are, Robin, Diana, Jonathan, grinning at each other like fools. Only Bloggs shows signs of nervousness, staring out of the van window. BLOGGS’S POV - Three race horses staring back at him from their horse boxes.  91 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOWN FROM CLOUDS to find a road cutting through Spanish countryside to the sea. The Bedford van is cruising down the road. Spanish road signs indicate TARRAGONA. IN THE VAN - The hiss of the respirator.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: The house is on the beach. I’ve got a long extension lead, so in theory Robin can stay out all day.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: There’s something else my chair needs... A parasol.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’ve brought pints of sun cream.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: We should charge up the chair battery.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Good idea. Bloggs, do you see the cable down here? I can’t take my eyes off the road.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: I see it.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: On the side of the wheelchair there’s a plug-board. Plug it into the second socket.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I see. He fumbles about in the shadowy space between the seats.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Second socket. Got it. He inserts the plug. BANG! The car swerves and lurches. Black smoke streams fr the respirator motor. The pump stops.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: For Christ’s sake!

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: God! God! What happened?  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 66. Diana steers the van up onto the verge, pulls on the brak and turns to the respirator. The van’s filling up with black smoke. Diana fumbles for the hand pump. Bloggs thro open the door. Diana starts to hand-pump. Robin breathes once more. Diana is badly frightened.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I knew something like this would happen. I just knew it. Bloggs is fanning the door to clear the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: What did I do?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I don’t know, but the respirator’s bust. (to Robin) You okay, Robin?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Bloggs, can you see what I’m doing? Do you think you can do it? Just maintain the same rhythm. Bloggs takes over the hand-pumping. Diana examines the respirator to see what’s broken, but it’s hard to get at it.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Let’s get the wheelchair out. Whatever you do, don’t stop pumping. She and Jonathan open the van’s back doors and lower the platform. Then with Bloggs doubled up working the hand pu they wheel the chair out onto the grass. Here Diana gets to work with a whole box of tools.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Do you know how to fix it? She gets the motor open: it’s melted.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: No. I don’t. She stares. This is a total disaster.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 67.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I just don’t know what I did. A SPANISH MOTORIST has pulled up to help.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH MOTORIST
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Do you speak English?

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH MOTORIST
dialogues.text: Little.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: We need a mechanic.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: For God's sake, Bloggs. We need to telephone. She mimes dialling. The Spanish motorist understands. He points down the road.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH MOTORIST
dialogues.text: Torredembarra. Telephone. I take you?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yes, please. Jonathan, get my handbag. Jonathan runs to the front seat of the van.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: No need to go so fast, Bloggs... I’m not a balloon. Jonathan is back with the handbag. Diana takes out her address book.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Bloggs, go with this man, find a phone, call Teddy Hall. Here’s his numbers. He'll either be at the lab or at his home. That’s the Littlemore number.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: In England?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Tell him what’s happened. We’1l wait for him here.  92 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 68.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Wait for him to fly out from England?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (tense) Just go. Please. She takes over the hand-pumping. Bloggs heads to the Spaniard’s car. Robin calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Get some bread, and sausage... And wine... And a corkscrew. Diana pumps away steadily. Robin looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’m not saying it. I hope you can hear me. I’m not saying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana, Bloggs and Jonathan sit round Robin in his wheelchair sharing a picnic supper. Jonathan is taking hi turn on the hand pump. The others drink wine straight fro the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Pleasant temperature... Reminds me of Nairobi.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: You okay there, Jonathan?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m fine. It’s quite easy, really.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: (to Diana) What’s the plan for the night?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: We'll take it in turns to sleep, one at a time. That leaves one to pump, and the other to make sure they don’t fall asleep.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Yes, please don’t fall asleep.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You're doing brilliantly, Jonathan. I'll take over in a moment.  93 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 69.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I’m okay. Really. A few cars go by, their headlights sweeping the little group by the van.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I wonder what on earth they think we're doing.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: El camping. The English are famous for not wanting to stray far from their cars. Diana feeds Robin wine through a straw, catching the dribbles with a handkerchief. Jonathan pumps away, watchi his father silhouetted against the evening sky. Robin’s eyes move to rest on Jonathan kneeling by his chair, keeping him alive. He smiles, and Jonathan smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonlight over the road and van. The sound of the hand pump in action. IN THE VAN - Jonathan asleep, prone on the back seat. Bloggs upright, eyelids drooping. Diana in the driver's seat, pumping away, very weary. Robin asleep in his wheelchair. Diana’s head droops, and she slips into sleep. The pump stops. Bloggs fails to notice. Robin’s eyes open. He makes his clicking noise. No one he More clicking. No response. Seconds pass. He closes his eyes. Seconds pass. Bloggs emits a sudden snore. Diana wakes.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Oh God! She starts pumping again. Robin opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Sorry. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I can go for longer than that.  94 95 Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small CROWD OF LOCALS has gathered round the van. Three cars are now pulled up on the verge beyond. The locals ha turned out with food, wine, sunshades, folding chairs, an a radio that plays cheerful pop music. Among the group is PRIEST. He has no English, so his remarks are translated a friendly local SPANISH WOMAN. In the midst of the festivity Robin sits under an awning, being fed by Diana and pumped by Jonathan.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH PRIEST
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Almighty God likes to play jokes on us. But his jokes are always for a purpose.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH WOMAN
dialogues.text: He say God make joke.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH PRIEST
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) This poor man’s suffering brings us all together in celebration.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH WOMAN
dialogues.text: So we have party.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Quite right. God has a joke... We have a party. The priest beams. Diana meets Robin’s eyes, and they shar a smile.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You know who’d have loved this?... Paddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DRIVER'S POV - Approaching down the road. A big crowd camped on the verge ahead, by the light of kerosene lanterns. It looks like some kind of outdoor religious festival. Closer, we make out dozens of cars lining the road. The crowd can now be seen to be centred on a trio of singing GUITARISTS. They play with great seriousness, and sing ve beautifully. The approaching car cruises to a stop close to the gathering. In the heart of the crowd, Robin sits in his wheelchair listening to the singers, blissfully happy.  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 70A. Beside him sits Diana, her hand holding his hand, also happier than she’s been in years.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 71. Behind her, Jonathan leans over them, his chin on her shoulder. Bloggs kneels by Robin’s chair, pumping away.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: You don’t need to worry about Mum. She’s stronger than anyone I know.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Quite right... How about you?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m all right.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I wish I could have done more for you.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: What? You’ve done loads for me, Dad. You’ve always been here.  Breathe - Salmon Revision - 26 July 2016 89A.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Couldn’t get away, could I?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Always listened to me. Always wanted to know what I’m doing. Never put me under any pressure. Always made life fun for me. I couldn’t have asked for a better dad.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Funny old world.  134 Breathe - Salmon Revision - 26 July 2016 90. Jonathan gently strokes Robin’s cheek. INT. ROBIN’S ROOM, FURLONGS - NIGHT 134 Robin lies in bed in the darkened bedroom. His eyes are open. The rhythmic sound of the respirator. He starts to gurgle. Spatters of blood appear round his breathing tube. His body spasms. Blood bursts out of his neck, staining t sheet. He activates his alarm. Diana comes running in, followed by Jonathan. Robin is no gushing blood. Diana takes hold of him, and is at once covered in blood.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Help me turn him onto his side. Jonathan moves in and is soon blood-soaked too. Diana gets Robin onto his side. The blood streams out of his neck. Robin’s eyes meet Jonathan’s. Jonathan sees there a look mute horror.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Do what you can to clean up the mess. She gets the suction tube and sets to work emptying the last of the blood from inside Robin’s lungs. Jonathan mop up round her. The breathing tube goes back in. Robin lies there, on his back once more, staring at the ceiling.  135 136 Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana stands by the kitchen sink, which is full of blood- soaked sheets. She has her arms tight round herself and she’s shaking al over. A silent disintegration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slow-moving procession through the trees: Robin in his wheelchair, Jonathan pushing him, Diana following behind. An echo of the earlier scene when Jonathan as a child rac along beside the wheelchair. Times have changed. They go slowly now. Jonathan pushes Robin out into the open and turns him to gaze out over the view. Diana joins them. ON ROBIN - Looking at the view.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I heard a story once, in Kenya... about a group of Mau Mau prisoners... sixty of them... Their leader said to his men... ‘I give you permission to die’... The next morning all sixty were dead. No one speaks.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: It's just a matter of will... I’ve gone on long enough. Diana stares at him, guessing what he’s going to say.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: August is a good month. When August comes... I’m going to let myself go. Diana moves round so that he can see her.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You'll be free at last. Suddenly Diana’s shouting -  137 138 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 92.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: No! NO! You stupid, stupid man! What do you think I’ve been doing all these years? Your life is my life too! She turns away and stamps off across the open grass. Jonathan makes a move to go after her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Let her go. They watch Diana as she circles away from them, and then heads back. She starts shouting when she’s still some distance away.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: All right! Have it your own way! You always do. She comes back to Robin and stands fiercely before him.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Just never, ever say you did it for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin Campbell has just arrived, and is heading into the house. Through the open window to Robin’s room he hears Robin’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I want to arrange a funeral. INT. ROBIN’S ROOM, FURLONGS - DAY 138 Robin has now become skilled at working his POSSUM machin He’s on the phone to an Oxford undertaker. UNDERTAKER’S VOICE I can assure you of the best service in Oxfordshire, sir. We had the honour of handling all the arrangements for Sir Winston Churchill’s funeral, Oxford end.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I just want to make it quite clear that I want the cheapest coffin you've got. UNDERTAKER’S VOICE The cheapest, sir?  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 93. Colin Campbell comes in and stands waiting, unseen, as Ro finishes his call.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: The cheapest. UNDERTAKER’S VOICE In respect for the deceased, sir -

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: The deceased doesn’t care. I should know. I am the deceased. UNDERTAKER’S VOICE (now uncertain) Ah, in that case... We pride ourselves on providing a bespoke service -

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. Just send me the details. Thank you. He ends the call, working the POSSUM machine.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: The deceased is very bossy, as usual. Robin’s face lights up at the sight of Colin.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Ah, Col! I’ve been waiting for you. How kind of you to come.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: What’s this about a funeral?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I want you to organise the wake.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Not for a few years yet, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Beginning of September.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: No, no. I’m not listening to any of this. We’ve got a bit more life in us than that, you and I.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You can hang around as long as you want... I’m off in August.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 93A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana is clearing up. Colin Campbell is helping her.  140 Breathe - Buff Revision - 15 July 2016 94.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: We must buck him up. Get him out of this morbid frame of mind. Make him see how much his friends need him. Diana works away in silence. Then -

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: We're not going to keep Robin alive for the benefit of his friends.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (startled) No. Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: But I expect they’d like to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE - The house and garden are overflowing with hundreds Robin’s friends. Beyond the garden, above the intervening trees, rises the square tower of the village church. Robin lies in his bed, which has been brought out onto th terrace, where he’s surrounded as always by young women. atmosphere is noisy and cheerful. Several of the guests a other responauts in Cavendish chairs with their carers, including Paddy with his carer, now wife, Nurse Margaret. A queue of people are lined up to speak to Robin. Bloggs and David Blacker look on.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: You know he’s telling everyone this is a leaving party?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What, even the girls?

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA HARRIS
dialogues.text: Robin, I can’t bear this! What am I supposed to say?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You say, About bloody time.

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA HARRIS
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea how much we're going to miss you?  Breathe - Buff Revision - 15 July 2016 95. Robin’s gaze is across the garden to where Jonathan stand with his arm round a pretty girl. Jonathan meets Robin’s eyes and grins. He says something to his girl she looks r and gives Robin a smile.

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: Is this really serious?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: It’s what Robin wants.

dialogues.speaker: MARY DAWNAY
dialogues.text: How on earth are you coping?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I don’t really know. I feel strange.

dialogues.speaker: BY ROBIN -
dialogues.text: Paddy is wheeled up to Robin by Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: What’s this I’m hearing? You’re planning another great escape?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Time to go... For me, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Just like the last time. Not waiting for your friends.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You're too slow for me, Paddy.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: But you’ll be back for me later, right? Robin smiles at him, moved.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Now that would be quite a trick.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: If anyone can do it, you can.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You owe me £5.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 O5A.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: (to Nurse Margaret) Maggie!  Breathe - Buff Revision - 15 July 2016 96. Nurse Margaret has a five pound note ready. She hands it Paddy, who gives it to Robin. Teddy Hall comes to Robin’s side, cradling a bottle of wi Jonathan joins them, accompanied by his girlfriend. Jonathan’s spotted the wine, and knows Teddy’s tastes.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: What have you got there, Teddy? With a flourish Teddy holds up his bottle of claret.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: It’s a '59 Saint-Emilion. My last bottle of one of the greatest wines ever made. Jonathan - glasses. Teddy takes out a corkscrew and opens the bottle. Jonatha fetches glasses. Harry Tennyson comes and sits on the chair beside Robin.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY TENNYSON
dialogues.text: Robin, we’ve known each other a long time. I just wanted to say - The chair buckles under his weight, sending him toppling the floor. Robin’s face crumples up with laughter. As he clambers to his feet, Teddy hands round glasses of wine. He raises his own glass in a toast.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: Here’s to you, Robin. The others echo the toast.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Jonathan... Jonathan steps into his eyeline.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Here, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: About my ashes... I’d like you to scatter them over the Ngong hills... They were the happiest days of my life.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Of course, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I don’t mean I’ve not been happy...  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 96A. He's embarrassed. Jonathan understands. He touches Robin' cheek to show affection the old way.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 97.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: It’s okay, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY HALL
dialogues.text: Do we have to talk about scattering ashes? It is all a little morbid.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I suppose death is a little morbid. The Blacker twins join them.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Robin, are we to take this seriously?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know about seriously... It’s all a bit of a joke, when you think about it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: But are we really supposed to be saying goodbye?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Matter of courtesy, David... One shouldn't leave a party without saying one’s farewells.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS
dialogues.text: Then we’d like to do it our way. He and David form up side by side. They come to attention salute, and start to sing.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS/DAVID
dialogues.text: Goodbye-ee, goodbye-ee Wipe the tear, baby dear, from your eye-ee Though it’s hard to part, I know - On Robin, mouthing the next line with them -

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS/DAVID
dialogues.text: I'll be tickled to death to go - The crowd of friends round Robin listens, laughs. Tears glisten in eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS/DAVID
dialogues.text: Don’t cry-ee, don’t sigh-ee There’s a silver lining in the sky- ee - They begin a synchronised march away, singing as they go  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 98.

dialogues.speaker: BLOGGS/DAVID
dialogues.text: Bonsoir old thing, cheerio chin- chin Na-poo, toodle-oo, goodbye-ee. Their march takes them into the shrubbery, out of sight. they come to a stop, and standing side by side, not looki at each other, they let the tears come. 141 INT. ROBIN’S ROOM, FURLONGS - NIGHT 141 Colin sits by Robin’s bed, his head in his hands, listeni to Robin.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I suppose I should be afraid, but I’m not... Stopping believing in God helps... No afterlife, nothing... Just the end of my innings... Head up high, back to the pavilion.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Bloody cricket.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Always loved that game. Beat. Colin lifts his head to look at Robin.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Something I have to say. I want you to know what a difference you've made to my life. It’s not always been easy for me. But every time I come here, I go away stronger. Not because you’re worse off than me. It’s who you are. Or who you’ve turned yourself into. God knows how.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Thanks, Col.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: You were always the great player. Cricket. Tennis. Girls. And you’ve had to live your life as a spectator. No more sixes. No more killer serves. No more - He gives a meaningful shrug.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: As it happens, that’s not been a problem... Just about the only part of me that’s worked.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 98A. Colin is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Unlikely as it may seem.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Well, hurrah for that! You really are a bloody miracle, Robin. There you are, stuck in a chair, stuck in bed, but there’s more life in you than anyone I’ve ever known. Bloody hell. I’m going to miss you. 142 INT. ROBIN’S ROOM, FURLONGS - DAY 142 A cricket match on the TV screen. Robin watching the matc He looks weary. His eyes close. The distant sound of Lee Marvin singing ‘Wand’ring Star’ -  143 144 145 Breathe - Cherry Revision - 28 July 2016 99.

dialogues.speaker: SONG
dialogues.text: When I get to heaven Tie me to a tree - For I‘ll begin to roam, and soon You’1l know where I will be - I was bo-orn Under a wand’rin’ star A wand’rin’, wand’rin’ star... A MEMORY FROM THE PAST — Young Robin at the cricket match from the start of the fi He’s striding out to bat, looking back at Diana. This tim she’s looking at him, smiling for him. Robin’s eyes open. He stares out at nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Who am I fooling?

dialogues.speaker: 147A
dialogues.text: 148 Breathe - Cherry Revision - 28 July 2016

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan drinking coffee in the kitchen with Diana.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Dad’s Mau-Mau thing isn’t working. It’s like a bad joke. How does a paralysed man commit suicide? He’s been telling everyone he’ll be gone by the end of the summer. I mean, it’s a matter of pride. He starts to laugh. Then the laugh stops.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, hell.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: He won't let me help him. Did he ask you?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: No. I wish he would. It would be something -— He looks away, afraid of revealing too much.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: - something I could give him. 100. 146 147

dialogues.speaker: 147A
dialogues.text: 148  Breathe - Cherry Revision - 28 July 2016 101-101A. 149 INT. ROBIN’S ROOM, FURLONGS - DAY 149 Robin in his wheelchair with Dr Clement Aitken by his sid They've been talking for some time.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Should be simple enough... think of it like putting down an injured racehorse.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMENT AITKEN
dialogues.text: You do know it’s against the law?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Who’s to know?

dialogues.speaker: CLEMENT AITKEN
dialogues.text: If Diana or Jonathan were to be involved, they could end up in prison.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: CLEMENT AITKEN
dialogues.text: Oh, me. I’ve been breaking the rules all my life. Just promise me you know what you’re asking.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I know what I’m asking.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMENT AITKEN
dialogues.text: I’ve never actually played God before.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You’1ll make a good God, Clem... All the God I need.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE DELETED 150
dialogues.text: Breathe - Cherry Revision - 28 July 2016 102. 151 INT. ROBIN’S ROOM, FURLONGS - NIGHT 151 Robin has had another bleed, and Diana is finishing cleaning him up. As she gathers up the blood-soaked sheet and turns to leave -

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Darling.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 102A. She pauses.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: That’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yes.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 103.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I expect you know... but just in case... No one could have loved you... as much as I’ve loved you.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: My love. My life. She reaches out to stroke his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Me too, Robin. My love. My life.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE DELETED 152
dialogues.text: 153 INT. ROBIN’S ROOM, FURLONGS - DAY 153 Robin is using his phone system, listening through an earphone.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Clem... It’s time. He listens to the person on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Today. Now. He listens again.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Like a military op, eh?... Synchronise watches... He listens, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Clem. I’1l be here. He operates the sensor to end the call. For a moment he lets his eyes close. He’s preparing himself. Then he uses the sensor again to ring his bell. Diana comes in.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Get Jonathan. Diana goes to the door and calls.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Jonathan!  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 104. Then, back by Robin’s side -

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: What’s this about?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: No questions. Jonathan comes in. One glance at his mother and he knows this is serious. They both turn their gaze on Robin.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I want you both to listen very carefully... You’re to do exactly as I say... This is very important... Promise me.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Diana takes Jonathan’s hand in hers.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I’ve come to the end... I want to rest, as they say, in peace.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Oh my darling.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Not yet... Soon.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Tell us what you want us to do, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You're to leave the house just before eleven-thirty this morning... Go down to the pub... You’re to come back at twelve noon... on the button.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Twelve noon. Okay. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Promise me I’1ll have time to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: There’1l be time.  154 155 Breathe - Tan Revision - 2 August 2016 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock on the church’s square timber-clad tower says twenty-five to twelve. Diana and Jonathan walk past the church to the pub. They walk in silence. A red car passes, driving fast towards Furlongs.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO -
dialogues.text: They're sitting at one of the outdoor pub tables, waiting in silence. Then -

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Mum -

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: No. Don’t say anything. She looks across towards the church clock. Ten to twelve. Nothing shows on her face, but beneath the table her hand is holding Jonathan's tight. A barmaid comes up.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAID
dialogues.text: So what can I get you all today?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Nothing for me, thanks. Mum? Diana shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAID
dialogues.text: Strictly speaking these tables are reserved for customers only, I know we’re not very busy right now, but what with it coming up to lunchtime, though a few minutes more won’t hurt -

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: It's okay. We’re just leaving. The red car comes past them down the road, driving away f Furlongs. A glimpse of the driver: Clement Aitken, lookin strained.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE DELETED 155
dialogues.text: 156 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING POV - Into the front hall. Across to the door to Robin’s room. Through the door into the room. Across the room to Robin's bed. There he lies, eyes closed, seemingly asleep. The respirator hisses away. The MOVING POV approaches Robin. His eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Still here. Diana and Jonathan sit down by his side.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I shall go to sleep very soon. Diana strokes Robin’s head and face. An unexpected peace settles over them. A rumble from Robin’s chest. Some flecks of blood appear his neck. Diana moves to clean him up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Leave it. Another beat of silence. ON DIANA as she strokes Robin’s face. She’s very calm, almost as if she’s accepted he’s gone already.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You go first, Jonathan. Jonathan kisses Robin’s cheek.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Bye, Dad. I love you. Robin gazes long into Jonathan's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: My son. My boy... You’ve given me more than you'll ever know. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I don’t have a farewell speech. You don’t mind, do you?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You've given me a wonderful life.  157 158 Breathe - Double White - 18 August 2016 107-108.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Not quite what you were expecting. He’s getting drowsy now.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Nor me.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I do love you, Robin.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: And I love you, my darling... My beautiful wife. Another beat of silence. Their eyes on each other. Then Robin’s eyes close. Diana leans close and kisses him. WIDE - Diana and Jonathan sitting by Robin’s bed in silence. Time passes. Jonathan takes Robin’s hand and feels gently for the puls on his wrist. He meets his mother’s eyes. Gives a small nod. Then he reaches out and switches off the respirator. Suddenly the silence is deafening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLYING LOW over lakes and plains. The red earth of Africa the dark green forests. A whole world away...
